content.text:
1. Background and Purpose 

With predictive modeling being an integral part of modern healthcare advancements, many 

researchers have applied Artificial Intelligence (AI) and statistical techniques to improve cancer 

prognosis. (National Library of Medicine, 2022) In breast cancer survival prediction, traditional 

models like the Cox Proportional Hazards model are widely used to estimate survival 

probabilities, but their predictive performance can be enhanced by integrating machine learning 

methods. Techniques such as neural networks and random forests offer unique strengths, 

including the ability to handle nonlinear interactions and high-dimensional data. 

 

This project aims to investigate and identify the optimal combination of the Cox Proportional 

Hazards model with machine learning methods to enhance survival prediction accuracy. By 

systematically evaluating these approaches, the project seeks to determine the most effective 

integration for improved risk stratification, survival curve estimation, and personalized treatment 

planning. 

 

2. Literature Review  

2.1 About the Cox Model 

The cox model is a regression technique used for performing survival analysis in 

epidemiological and clinical research. (National Library of Medicine, 2021) It is based on the 

hazards function, and is written mathematically as ℎ(𝑡; 𝑥) = ℎ0(𝑡) × 𝑒𝑥𝑝 [𝑏1𝑥1 +

𝑏2𝑥2+. . . +𝑏𝑘𝑥𝑘], where ℎ(𝑡; 𝑥) is the hazard function at time 𝑡 for subject with covariate values 

𝑥1,...,𝑥𝑘, ℎ0(𝑡) is the baseline hazard function, 𝑒𝑥𝑝 is the exponential function 𝑒𝑥, 𝑥𝑖 is the 𝑖th 

covariate in the model and 𝑏𝑖 is the regression coefficient for the 𝑖th covariate 𝑥𝑖. (University of 

Michigan, 2006) Due to the baseline hazard function ℎ0(𝑡) being assumed to be unknown, in 

order to see the proportional hazards model analytically, we have to take the ratio of ℎ(𝑡; 𝑥) for 

two different covariate values, for example 𝑥𝑖 and 𝑥𝑗, which will give us an equation like 

this:
ℎ(𝑡;𝑥𝑖)

ℎ(𝑡;𝑥𝑗)
=

ℎ0𝑡 × 𝑒𝑥𝑝 [𝑏1𝑥𝑖1+𝑏2𝑥𝑖2+...+𝑏𝑘𝑥𝑖𝑘] 

ℎ0𝑡 × 𝑒𝑥𝑝 [𝑏1𝑥𝑗1+𝑏2𝑥𝑗2+...+𝑏𝑘𝑥𝑗𝑘]
= 𝑒𝑥𝑝 [𝑏1(𝑥𝑖1 − 𝑥𝑗1) + 𝑏2(𝑥𝑖2 − 𝑥𝑗2)+. . . +𝑏𝑘(𝑥𝑖𝑘 −

𝑥𝑗𝑘)].  



We chose to use the cox model as it is ideal for performing cancer survival analysis for our 

project as it is able to evaluate the effect that many factors have on survival at the same time, 

which is useful for our research by allowing us to see how our factors influence the survival rate 

of cancer patients across a period of time, and is realistic to real-world situations as it accounts 

for censorship  

2.2 Accounting for Censorship in the Cox model 

Censoring is a feature whereby the time-to-event analysis precludes or excludes observation of 

the event (National Library of Medicine, 2018), which can be further broken down into 3 

different types: left censoring, which occurs when it is known the event happened at time t, but 

the initial time of occurrence is unknown, right censoring, which occurs when the event happens 

after the start of the observation and interval censoring, whereby the random variable of interest 

is known to only lie with a certain interval instead of being observed directly. (National Library 

of Medicine, 2010) The Cox model accounts for this censorship by incorporating it into the 

likelihood function, which is why we decided to use the Cox model as this makes it suitable for 

real-world scenarios.  

Firstly, suppose we have our patients, 𝑝, where the mean time-to-failure, which in our case is 

time-to-death, has the survival function 𝑆 and density function 𝑓, both of which are 

parameterised by a parameter 𝜃. If the patient is observed to have passed away at time 0 ≤ 𝑡𝑖 ≤

𝑇, then we will incorporate it into the likelihood function using 𝑓(𝑡𝑖|𝜃), in which case there is no 

right censorship as the result of the patient passing away is within our observation period. 

However, if the patient is observed to have survived through our entire observation period from 0 

to 𝑇, we will not know whether or not the result of the patient passing away has happened, thus 

this will be considered a right censored data point, and we will incorporate it into the likelihood 

function 𝑆(𝑇|𝜃) instead.  

Assuming our survival model is based on the observing only for an observation period of 𝑇 and 

the time-to-death are all independently and identically distributed (IID) conditional on some 

underlying parameters, then without further loss of generality, we will observe 𝑛 observed failure 

times 𝑡1,...,𝑡𝑛 within our observation period of [0, 𝑇] and 𝑚 right censored values that did not fail 

within time 𝑇, as they happen after our observation period has ended. The overall likelihood 

function for this data is then given by 𝐿𝑡(𝜃)  =  (∏𝑛
𝑖=1 𝑓(𝑡𝑖|𝜃)) × 𝑆(𝑇|𝜃)𝑚.  



Through this likelihood function, we can see how censorship is accounted for as the censoring of 

data is “built in” as right-censored values are incorporated through their survival function instead 

of the density function for the time-to-death. 

Considering these, we can now extend to the Cox model, which also uses the likelihood function 

for observing time-to-death and survival times, but now adds in covariates, which are 

independent variables that can influence the outcome of a given statistical trial, but which is not 

of direct interest, to the data and uses an assumption of proportional hazards in how these 

manifest in the hazard function. While the method in which the censored data are built into the 

likelihood function is still similar to the above survival model, there is a possibility that we 

observe items up to different endpoints, in which case right-censored values would occur with 

different observation periods 𝑡𝑛+1,...,𝑡𝑛+𝑚. In this case, the likelihood function would be 

generalised to: 𝐿𝑡(𝜃)  =  (∏𝑛
𝑖=1 𝑓(𝑡𝑖|𝜃)) × (∏𝑚

𝑖=1 𝑆(𝑡𝑛+1|𝜃)𝑚), thus showing how the Cox 

model accounts for right censorship. 

For the case of left censorship, which means the patient has died before our observation period 

𝑇𝑖, the left-censored observations will enter into the likelihood function through the cumulative 

distribution function 𝐹, whereby the cumulative distribution function gives us the probability 

that the random variable 𝑋 is less than or equal to 𝑥. Extending this to our model again, 

assuming we have 𝑟 left-censored observations with observation times 𝑡𝑚+𝑛+𝑖,...,𝑡𝑚+𝑛+𝑟 then the 

likelihood function would be further generalised to: 𝐿𝑡(𝜃)  =  (∏𝑛
𝑖=1 𝑓(𝑡𝑖|𝜃)) ×

(∏𝑚
𝑖=1 𝑆(𝑡𝑛+1|𝜃)𝑚) × (∏𝑟

𝑖=1 𝐹(𝑡𝑚+𝑛+𝑖 |𝜃)), thus showing how the Cox model accounts for 

left censorship. 

Thus, this shows how the Cox model is ideal for our cancer-survival analysis, owing to how it, 

unlike other survival models, accounts for censorship, which is useful for real-life scenarios. 

 

2.3 About Random Forest 

Random Forest is a method that is based on taking the combination of predictive trees, also 

known as weak classifiers, whereby each tree is constructed from a random selection of samples 

and variables. One unique benefit of Random Forest is that it has higher discriminatory power 

compared to other models. (Science Direct, 2019)  

 

2. About Deep Learning 



Deep learning is a subfield of artificial intelligence that focuses on creating large neural network 

models that are capable of making data-driven decisions. Some of the tasks that deep learning is 

most capable of performing includes classification, regression, and representation learning. One 

of the benefits of using deep learning is that it is suitable for contests whereby the data is 

complex and the datasets are large.  (The Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 2019)  

 

3. Methodology  

3.1 Continuous Improvement of Models  

Initially, after hyperparameter tuning, the standalone Cox Proportional Hazards model yielded 

the following C-index values, detailed in Annex A. The model was trained on the SEER dataset, 

which comprises clinical and demographic information of breast cancer patients; specifics of this 

dataset are provided in Annex B.  

 

3.2 Integration of Predictive Techniques    

To improve the model, the baseline Cox Proportional Hazards model was paired with advanced 

machine learning methods, namely Neural Networks and Random Forests.. To predict survival 

rates, a two-step approach is employed. First, a random forest model and a deep learning neural 

network were used to calculate a risk score for each patient based on the features from the SEER 

dataset. The risk score represents the likelihood of death based on input features derived from 

patient data.  

 

The risk scores calculated from the machine learning model are integrated into the Cox model as 

covariates. The model estimates hazard ratios based on these scores, enabling the prediction of 

survival curves for individual patients. Survival curves represent the probability of surviving 

beyond a specific time point, offering detailed insights into patient prognosis. (Refer to Annex C 

for an example of a survival curve generated) 

 

4. Interpretation of Data, Results, and Findings  

To evaluate our models' performance in predicting risk scores, we utilized Harrell's Concordance 

Index (C-index), a metric that measures the agreement between predicted and actual event 

orderings in survival analysis. (Owkin, 2023) 

(The results of the models can be found in Annex A) 

Based on the data, it is evident that the Random Forest model was able to better predict the risk 

scores compared to the deep learning model. Additionally, when paired with the Cox 

Proportional Hazards model, the Random Survival Forest model resulted in a higher C-index, 

demonstrating better concordance between the predicted and actual survival outcomes. As a 



result, we chose this combination of the Cox model and Random Forest as our final improved 

model to predict breast cancer survival rates.  

 

5. Conclusion and Recommendation 

As demonstrated throughout the analysis, the ability to input a patient's specific features and 

generate an accurate survival curve is an invaluable tool for breast cancer patients and their 

medical teams. The final model we've developed, which combines the predictive power of the 

Random Survival Forest algorithm with the Cox Proportional Hazards model, has shown a strong 

C-index, indicating a high level of accuracy in predicting survival rates. This is a significant 

achievement because it allows for more precise risk assessments, helping doctors make better-

informed decisions regarding treatment plans and the patient’s prognosis. 

 

In real-life applications, this model has the potential to be a game-changer in clinical settings. By 

using this model, healthcare providers can tailor treatment options to each individual patient 

based on their predicted survival curve, rather than relying on generic approaches. This 

personalized strategy can ultimately improve patient outcomes and contribute to more targeted 

therapies, ultimately giving patients and doctors the confidence to make decisions that align with 

the best possible survival outcomes. 

The model’s ability to provide accurate predictions with just a few key features makes it a crucial 

tool in the fight against breast cancer, offering hope for more precise and effective care. 

 

 

 

 

6. Future Work 

A key next step for this project is to pilot the model in real-world clinical settings, particularly in 

hospitals and cancer treatment centers. By implementing the model in a controlled clinical 

environment, we can assess its practicality and performance when used by medical professionals. 

This would allow doctors to input patient data and generate survival curves to aid in decision-

making for breast cancer treatment. Feedback from healthcare providers during this phase would 

be invaluable for identifying areas where the model can be refined, whether through improving 

the accuracy of predictions or making the interface more user-friendly for clinical use. 

Ultimately, piloting the model in real-life settings would provide important insights into its 

effectiveness, ensuring that it is a reliable and impactful tool for improving patient outcomes in 

breast cancer care. 

 



7. Bibliography of References

Estrogen Status: Estrogen status is either positive (cells of this type of breast cancer have 

receptors that allow them to use the hormone estrogen to grow) or negative (cells of this type of 

breast cancer do not have receptors that allow them to use the hormone estrogen to grow) 

Progesterone Status: Is also either positive (cells have receptors that allow them to use this 

progesterone hormone to grow) or negative (cells do not have receptors that allow them to use 

this progesterone hormone to grow) 

Regional Node Examined: Records the total number of regional lymph nodes that were removed 

and examined by the pathologist. 

Regional Node Positive: Records the exact number of regional lymph nodes examined by the 

pathologist that were found to contain metastases. 

T Stage: Describes the size of the primary tumor in 4 different stages. 

N Stage: The N category of the TNM staging system is used to indicate if the breast cancer has 

spread to surrounding lymph nodes (N). A higher number represents that a greater number of 

lymph nodes impacted. 

Grade: Cancer cells are given a grade when they are removed from the breast and checked in the 

lab. The grade is based on how much the cancer cells look like normal cells. 

Age at Diagnosis: Age of patient at diagnosis 

 

Dependent variables:  



Survival Months: : Created using complete dates, including days, therefore may differ from 

survival time calculated from year and month only. 

Status: Alive or dead as of the cut-off date 

 

 

 

Annex C
content.title: Ro024 Project Report.pdf

parts: All the files uploaded by the user have been fully loaded. Searching won't provide additional information.

Here’s a critique of the project report based on the content provided:

---

### Strengths:
1. **Clear Objective**:
   - The report clearly identifies the goal of improving cancer survival prediction by integrating machine learning methods with the Cox Proportional Hazards model.
   - It emphasizes the practical utility of personalized survival curve estimation for clinical decision-making.

2. **Comprehensive Literature Review**:
   - The explanation of the Cox model, its assumptions, and its handling of censoring is well-detailed.
   - Inclusion of Random Forest and deep learning sections offers a broader context for the machine learning techniques used.

3. **Methodology**:
   - The integration of risk scores derived from Random Forest and Neural Networks into the Cox model demonstrates innovation.
   - Use of a two-step process for survival prediction ensures clarity in the methodological approach.

4. **Data and Metrics**:
   - Harrell's Concordance Index (C-index) is an appropriate metric for evaluating survival models.
   - Tabular presentation of results (in Annex A) offers transparency and allows comparison across methods.

5. **Real-World Application**:
   - The emphasis on piloting the model in clinical settings bridges the gap between research and application, showing foresight.

---

### Areas for Improvement:
1. **Clarity in Writing**:
   - The text could be more concise. Some sections, like the detailed mathematical derivation of the Cox model, are overly technical for a general audience. It would be helpful to move this into an appendix if targeting a broader audience.
   - There are occasional grammatical inconsistencies (e.g., "censorship" instead of "censoring").

2. **Literature Review Depth**:
   - While the Cox model and Random Forest are well-explained, the deep learning section is superficial. Including details about the neural network architecture, layers, and activation functions would improve technical depth.

3. **Results Interpretation**:
   - The report states that the Cox model with Random Survival Forest outperforms other methods, but the analysis lacks depth. For example:
     - Why does Random Survival Forest perform better?
     - How does the model generalize across diverse patient demographics?
   - Including confidence intervals or statistical significance tests for the C-index values would enhance credibility.

4. **Data Preprocessing**:
   - The report mentions preprocessing (Annex B), but the steps are not explicitly described. Were missing values imputed? Were features normalized or scaled?

5. **Visual Aids**:
   - While survival curves are mentioned (Annex C), they are not shown in the text. Including visualizations of survival curves or feature importance from the Random Forest model would make the findings more accessible.

6. **Future Work**:
   - The recommendation to pilot the model in clinical settings is commendable but lacks specificity. For example:
     - What challenges are anticipated in real-world deployment?
     - How will patient privacy and data security be managed?

7. **References**:
   - Some references lack complete citations (e.g., page numbers, publication details). Ensuring all references adhere to a consistent format would enhance professionalism.

---

### Suggestions for Further Enhancements:
1. Add a brief "Key Findings" section in the results to summarize insights in a non-technical manner.
2. Provide a direct comparison of the computational efficiency of the models (e.g., training time).
3. Highlight potential limitations, such as sample size, feature availability, or biases in the dataset.

---

Overall, the project report is solid and demonstrates a strong understanding of survival analysis and machine learning. Addressing the outlined areas for improvement would enhance its clarity, rigor, and appeal to a broader audience.
